original: rigs kyi bu /

analyzed: yang kha cig 'di skad du nam mkha' ni thogs pa med de /

analyzed: ji ltar bya dag shing la 'dus pa dang 'dra'o // las thun mong pa myong bas 'brel pa ste /

analyzed: lag pa gnyis gcig la @379a *//

analyzed: 'brel pas thun mong par 'brel pa ste / sor mo gnyis lhan cig tu bsdams pa dang 'dra'o //

analyzed: gal te nam mkha'i las rdzas dang 'brel par gyur na /

analyzed: nam mkha' ni mi rtag par mi 'gyur ro //

original: gal te kun tu ma khyab na de'ang mi rtag pa'o //
analyzed: gal te kun tu ma khyab na de'ang mi rtag pa'o //

original: gal te nam mkha' ni rtag pa yin te /
analyzed: gal te nam mkha' ni rtag pa yin te /

analyzed: de'ang de lta ma yin no //

original: de ci'i phyir zhe na /
analyzed: de ci'i phyir zhe na /

analyzed: gal te nam mkha' rtag na rdzas kyang rtag pa'i rigs so //

analyzed: gal te rdzas mi rtag na nam mkha' yang mi rtag go /

original: gal te nam mkha' ni rtag pa yin la /
analyzed: gal te nam mkha' ni rtag pa yin la /

analyzed: mi rtag pa'ang yin no zhes smra na de ni gnas med do //
translated: and also impermanent, that is impossible.

original: gal te thun mong ba'i las dang 'brel lo zhes smra na /
analyzed: gal te thun mong ba'i las dang 'brel lo zhes smra na /
translated: If you say that it is related to a shared substance,

original: de yang de lta ma yin no //
analyzed: de yang de lta ma yin no //
translated: that is not so.

original: de ci'i phyir zhe na /
analyzed: de ci'i phyir zhe na /
translated: Why is it not so?

original: nam mkha' ni kun tu khyab pa ste /
analyzed: nam mkha' ni kun tu khyab pa ste /

original: gal te las dang 'brel pa zhig yin na /
analyzed: gal te las dang 'brel pa zhig yin na /

original: las kyang kun tu khyab pa'i rigs so //
analyzed: las kyang kun tu khyab pa'i rigs so //

original: gal te kun tu khyab pa yin na /
analyzed: gal te kun tu khyab pa yin na /

original: thams cad du khyab par 'gyur ro //
analyzed: thams cad du khyab par 'gyur ro //

analyzed: thams @379b cad du khyab par gyur na thams cad dang 'brel pa'i rigs kyi /

analyzed: 'brel pas thun mong dang 'brel par 'gyur te /

analyzed: mdzub mo gnyis lhan cig bsdams pa dang 'dra'o zhes bya ba de'ang de lta ma yin no //

original: rigs kyi bu /

original: de ltar dus gcig tu tshad du phyin par skye ba'i gnas med de /
analyzed: de ltar dus gcig tu tshad du phyin par skye ba'i gnas med de /
translated: But there is no such thing as growing to full size all at once.

original: de bas na nges par skad cig skad cig gis 'gog pa'i mi rtag pa phra mo yod par rig go /
analyzed: de bas na nges par skad cig skad cig gis 'gog pa'i mi rtag pa phra mo yod par rig go /
translated: Therefore, we know that there is a subtle impermanence that is moment by moment cessation.

original: gzhan yang gang zag kha cig ni sngon dbang po dang mdog tu ldan te; phyis rgud cing nyams pa'ang mthong bas na gang zag de ni skad cig skad cig gis nges par mi rtag par mngon no //
analyzed: gzhan yang gang zag kha cig ni sngon dbang po dang mdog tu ldan te; phyis rgud cing nyams pa'ang mthong bas na gang zag de ni skad cig skad cig gis nges par mi rtag par mngon no //
translated: Moreover, we see that some people are well endowed with faculties and complexion in the beginning, but later we see them ruined and impaired. Therefore, we know that people are definitely impermanent from moment to moment.

original: gzhan yang chen po bzhi dang / spyod lam bzhi la rtog go /
analyzed: gzhan yang chen po bzhi dang / spyod lam bzhi la rtog go /
translated: Moreover, he contemplates the four great elements and the four modes of behavior.

original: gzhan yang phyi nang rnam pa gnyis la sdug bsngal gyi rgyu rnam pa gnyis gnyis yod de /
analyzed: gzhan yang phyi nang rnam pa gnyis la sdug bsngal gyi rgyu rnam pa gnyis gnyis yod de /
translated: Moreover, he contemplates the two kinds of suffering and the two kinds of causes of suffering, which are internal and external.

original: bkres pa dang / skom pa dang / grang ba dang / tsha ba yang rtog go /
analyzed: bkres pa dang / skom pa dang / grang ba dang / tsha ba yang rtog go /
translated: He contemplates hunger, thirst, cold, and heat.

original: gzhan yang de ltar rnam pa bzhi po de skad cig gis mi rtag pa phra mo ma yin na sdug bsngal rnam pa bzhi po'ang gsung ba'i mi rigs so snyam du sems so //
analyzed: gzhan yang de ltar rnam pa bzhi po de skad cig gis mi rtag pa phra mo ma yin na sdug bsngal rnam pa bzhi po'ang gsung ba'i mi rigs so snyam du sems so //
translated: Moreover, if the four modes of behavior are not subtle impermanence, then it would be unreasonable to say that the four kinds of suffering are also not subtle.

original: byang chub sems dpa' gang gis de ltar rtog na de ni byang chub sems dpa' mi rtag pa phra mo la rtog pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: byang chub sems dpa' gang gis de ltar rtog na de ni byang chub sems dpa' mi rtag pa phra mo la rtog pa zhes bya'o //
translated: If a bodhisattva contemplates in this way, this is called the bodhisattva‚Äôs contemplation of subtle impermanence.

original: phyi nang gi gzugs la ji lta ba bzhin du sems kyi chos kyang de bzhin du rig par bya'o //
analyzed: phyi nang gi gzugs la ji lta ba bzhin du sems kyi chos kyang de bzhin du rig par bya'o //
translated: Just as with external and internal form, so it is with mental phenomena.

original: de ci'i phyir @411a *//
analyzed: de ci'i phyir @411a *//
translated: Why is this?

original: zhe na / skye mched drug la spyod pa'i phyir ro //
analyzed: zhe na / skye mched drug la spyod pa'i phyir ro //
translated: Because they are experienced in the six sense bases.

original: skye mched drug la spyod pa na bar bar ni dga' ba'i sems skye /
analyzed: skye mched drug la spyod pa na bar bar ni dga' ba'i sems skye /
translated: When experiencing the six sense bases, sometimes a mind of joy arises,

original: bar bar ni zhe sdang gi sems skye /
analyzed: bar bar ni zhe sdang gi sems skye /
translated: sometimes a mind of anger arises,

original: bar bar ni 'dod pa'i sems skye /
analyzed: bar bar ni 'dod pa'i sems skye /
translated: sometimes a mind of desire arises,

original: bar bar ni dran pa'i sems skye ste /
analyzed: bar bar ni dran pa'i sems skye ste /
translated: and sometimes a mind of mindfulness arises.

original: de ltar tha dad pa'i sems skye ste /
analyzed: de ltar tha dad pa'i sems skye ste /
translated: Thus, different minds arise.

original: gcig tu ma chad pas gzugs kyi chos dang gzugs ma yin pa'i chos thams cad mi rtag par rig go /
analyzed: gcig tu ma chad pas gzugs kyi chos dang gzugs ma yin pa'i chos thams cad mi rtag par rig go /
translated: Since they are not cut off as one, one should know that all phenomena, whether having form or not having form, are impermanent.

original: rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: rigs kyi bu /
translated: Son of noble family,

original: byang chub sems dpa' gang zhig skad cig skad cig la chos thams cad skye ba dang / 'gog pa dang / mi rtag par mthong ba ni byang chub sems dpa' mi rtag pa'i 'du shes dang ldan pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: byang chub sems dpa' gang zhig skad cig skad cig la chos thams cad skye ba dang / 'gog pa dang / mi rtag par mthong ba ni byang chub sems dpa' mi rtag pa'i 'du shes dang ldan pa zhes bya'o //
translated: a bodhisattva who sees the arising, cessation, and impermanence of all phenomena in every moment is called a bodhisattva who possesses the perception of impermanence.

original: rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: rigs kyi bu /
translated: Son of noble family,

original: mkhas pa shes rab can ni de ltar mi rtag pa'i 'du shes la nan tan byas nas rtag pa'i nga rgyal dang / rtag pa'i phyin ci log dang / phyin ci log gi 'du shes yongs su spong ste /
analyzed: mkhas pa shes rab can ni de ltar mi rtag pa'i 'du shes la nan tan byas nas rtag pa'i nga rgyal dang / rtag pa'i phyin ci log dang / phyin ci log gi 'du shes yongs su spong ste /
translated: the wise and the learned, having thus practiced the perception of impermanence, abandon the pride of permanence, the error of permanence, and the perception of error.

original: sdug bsngal gyi 'du shes la nan tan byed do //
analyzed: sdug bsngal gyi 'du shes la nan tan byed do //
translated: He will then reflect on the notion of suffering.

original: ci'i rgyu ci'i rkyen gyis 'di ltar sdug bsngal myong bar 'gyur snyam bsams na sdug bsngal de ni mi rtag pa'i rgyu las byung bar shes so //
analyzed: ci'i rgyu ci'i rkyen gyis 'di ltar sdug bsngal myong bar 'gyur snyam bsams na sdug bsngal de ni mi rtag pa'i rgyu las byung bar shes so //
translated: ‚Äú ‚ÄòWhat is the cause and what is the condition for experiencing such suffering?‚Äô He will then think, ‚ÄúThis suffering arises from the cause of impermanence.‚Äù

original: mi rtag pa'i rkyen gyis skye ba dang / rga ba dang / na ba dang / shi ba myong bar gyur te /
analyzed: mi rtag pa'i rkyen gyis skye ba dang / rga ba dang / na ba dang / shi ba myong bar gyur te /
translated: ‚Äú ‚ÄòThe condition of impermanence causes the experience of birth, aging, sickness, and death.

original: skye ba dang / rga ba dang / na ba dang / shi ba'i rkyen gyis mi rtag pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: skye ba dang / rga ba dang / na ba dang / shi ba'i rkyen gyis mi rtag pa zhes bya'o //
translated: The condition of birth, aging, sickness, and death is called impermanence.

original: mi rtag pa'i rkyen gyis phyi nang gi sdug bsngal mang po myong ba ni bkres pa dang / @411b skom pa dang / grang ba dang / tsha pa dang / rdeg pa dang / 'tshog pa dang / spyo ba dang / gshe ba'i sdug bsngal myong ngo //
analyzed: mi rtag pa'i rkyen gyis phyi nang gi sdug bsngal mang po myong ba ni bkres pa dang / @411b skom pa dang / grang ba dang / tsha pa dang / rdeg pa dang / 'tshog pa dang / spyo ba dang / gshe ba'i sdug bsngal myong ngo //
translated: ‚Äú ‚ÄòThe condition of impermanence causes the experience of many kinds of suffering, both external and internal. One experiences the suffering of hunger, thirst, cold, heat, beating, striking, scolding, and abuse.

original: de ltar sdug bsngal mang po myong ba'ang mi rtag pa'i rkyen gyis myong bar gyur to //
analyzed: de ltar sdug bsngal mang po myong ba'ang mi rtag pa'i rkyen gyis myong bar gyur to //
translated: ‚Äú ‚ÄòThe experience of such many kinds of suffering is due to the condition of impermanence.üîΩ‚Äú ‚Äò

original: gzhan yang mkhas pa shes rab can ni lus 'di la mi rtag pa'i snod yin par rtog go /
analyzed: gzhan yang mkhas pa shes rab can ni lus 'di la mi rtag pa'i snod yin par rtog go /
translated: Moreover, the wise and the learned consider that this body is a vessel of impermanence.

original: snod sdug bsngal ba yin te /
analyzed: snod sdug bsngal ba yin te /
translated: The vessel is suffering.

original: de ltar snod sdug bsngal ba yin pas bcud kyang de dang 'dra bar sdug bsngal gyi chos yin par rtog go /
analyzed: de ltar snod sdug bsngal ba yin pas bcud kyang de dang 'dra bar sdug bsngal gyi chos yin par rtog go /
translated: Since the vessel is like that, the wise and the learned consider that the contents are also a phenomenon of suffering.

original: gzhan yang / rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: gzhan yang / rigs kyi bu /
translated: ‚ÄúSon of noble family,

original: mkhas pa shes rab can ni skye ba nyid kyang sdug bsngal bar rtog la /
analyzed: mkhas pa shes rab can ni skye ba nyid kyang sdug bsngal bar rtog la /
translated: the wise and the learned consider that birth itself is suffering.

original: 'gog pa'ang sdug bsngal bar rtog ste /
analyzed: 'gog pa'ang sdug bsngal bar rtog ste /
translated: They consider that cessation is suffering.

original: sdug bsngal gyis skye zhing 'gog pas na mi rtag pa yin te /
analyzed: sdug bsngal gyis skye zhing 'gog pas na mi rtag pa yin te /
translated: Since it is born from suffering and ceases through suffering, it is impermanent.

original: bdag dang bdag gi ba ma yin par mi rtag pa'i 'du shes la nan tan byed do //
analyzed: bdag dang bdag gi ba ma yin par mi rtag pa'i 'du shes la nan tan byed do //
translated: They are diligent in the perception of impermanence, which is neither a self nor that which belongs to a self.

original: gzhan yang mkhas pa shes rab can ni sdug bsngal nyid mi rtag pa yin la /
analyzed: gzhan yang mkhas pa shes rab can ni sdug bsngal nyid mi rtag pa yin la /
translated: Moreover, the wise and the learned consider that suffering itself is impermanent.

original: mi rtag pa nyid kyang sdug bsngal ba yin te /
analyzed: mi rtag pa nyid kyang sdug bsngal ba yin te /
translated: Impermanence itself is suffering.

original: de ltar sdug bsngal ba nyid mi rtag pa yin pas na mkhas pa shes rab can gyis ci'i phyir bdag yod ces smra /
analyzed: de ltar sdug bsngal ba nyid mi rtag pa yin pas na mkhas pa shes rab can gyis ci'i phyir bdag yod ces smra /
translated: learned say that the self exists?üîΩSince it is not the self, impermanence should be understood in the same

original: de ltar bdag ma yin pas na mi rtag pa'ang de bzhin du rig par bya'o //
analyzed: de ltar bdag ma yin pas na mi rtag pa'ang de bzhin du rig par bya'o //
translated: way.

original: de bzhin du phung po lnga'ang sdug bsngal ba'ang yin la mi rtag pa'ang yin na sems can gyis ci'i phyir bdag yod ces smra /
analyzed: de bzhin du phung po lnga'ang sdug bsngal ba'ang yin la mi rtag pa'ang yin na sems can gyis ci'i phyir bdag yod ces smra /
translated: In the same way, since the five aggregates are both suffering and impermanent, why would sentient beings say that the self exists?

original: gzhan yang chos thams cad ni tha dad 'dus pa las skyes kyi /üîΩgcig bu zhig 'dus pa las chos thams cad skyes pa'ang ma @412a *//
analyzed: gzhan yang chos thams cad ni tha dad 'dus pa las skyes kyi / gcig bu zhig 'dus pa las chos thams cad skyes pa'ang ma @412a *//
translated: Moreover, all phenomena arise from the aggregation of differences.üîΩNo phenomenon arises from the aggregation of a single thing.

original: yin la / chos gcig kyang thams cad 'dus pa'i 'bras bu ma yin par rtogs te /
analyzed: yin la / chos gcig kyang thams cad 'dus pa'i 'bras bu ma yin par rtogs te /
translated: Nor is any single phenomenon the effect of the aggregation of all things.

original: 'dus pa thams cad bdag gi rang bzhin yang med /üîΩgcig pa'i rang bzhin yang med /
analyzed: 'dus pa thams cad bdag gi rang bzhin yang med / gcig pa'i rang bzhin yang med /
translated: All aggregations are devoid of the nature of the self.üîΩThey are also devoid of the nature of unity.

original: tha dad pa'i rang bzhin yang med /üîΩdngos po'i rang bzhin yang med /
analyzed: tha dad pa'i rang bzhin yang med / dngos po'i rang bzhin yang med /
translated: They are also devoid of the nature of multiplicity.üîΩThey are also devoid of the nature of substance.

original: dbang du gyur pa'i rang bzhin yang med do //
analyzed: dbang du gyur pa'i rang bzhin yang med do //
translated: They are also devoid of the nature of control.

original: chos thams cad la gal te rang bzhin gyi mtshan nyid de dag yod na mkhas pa shes rab can gyis ci'i phyir bdag yod par smra /
analyzed: chos thams cad la gal te rang bzhin gyi mtshan nyid de dag yod na mkhas pa shes rab can gyis ci'i phyir bdag yod par smra /
translated: If all phenomena had such characteristics of intrinsic identity, then why would the wise and the learned say that the self exists?

original: gzhan yang 'di snyam du chos thams cad la chos gcig tsam yang byed pa po med do //
analyzed: gzhan yang 'di snyam du chos thams cad la chos gcig tsam yang byed pa po med do //
translated: Moreover, if you think like this, then not a single phenomenon has an agent.

original: de ltar chos gcig tsam yang byed pa po med de /
analyzed: de ltar chos gcig tsam yang byed pa po med de /
translated: Thus, not a single phenomenon has an agent.

original: chos thams cad 'dus pa las byed pa po yang med do //
analyzed: chos thams cad 'dus pa las byed pa po yang med do //
translated: All phenomena are without an agent due to the aggregation of all phenomena.

original: chos thams cad rang bzhin gyis rang skye ba'am /
analyzed: chos thams cad rang bzhin gyis rang skye ba'am /
translated: All phenomena do not arise by themselves due to their intrinsic nature.

original: rang 'gog par mi 'gyur te /
analyzed: rang 'gog par mi 'gyur te /
translated: Nor do they cease by themselves.

original: 'dus pa las 'gog cing 'dus pa las skye ste /
analyzed: 'dus pa las 'gog cing 'dus pa las skye ste /
translated: They cease due to the aggregation and arise due to the aggregation.

original: de ltar chos skyes nas sems can gyis phyin ci log pa'i 'du shes bskyed de /
analyzed: de ltar chos skyes nas sems can gyis phyin ci log pa'i 'du shes bskyed de /
translated: Thus, after a phenomenon arises, sentient beings generate a distorted perception.

original: 'dus pa las skye'o zhes smra'o //
analyzed: 'dus pa las skye'o zhes smra'o //
translated: They say, ‚ÄúIt arises due to the aggregation.‚Äù

original: sems can gyis phyin ci log tu 'du shes pas yang dag pa'i bden pa med na ci'i phyir yang dag par bdag yod do zhes smra /
analyzed: sems can gyis phyin ci log tu 'du shes pas yang dag pa'i bden pa med na ci'i phyir yang dag par bdag yod do zhes smra /
translated: If sentient beings have a distorted perception and there is no true reality, then why do they say, ‚ÄúThe self truly exists‚Äù?

original: de bas na mkhas pa shes rab can ni bdag med par rtog go /
analyzed: de bas na mkhas pa shes rab can ni bdag med par rtog go /
translated: Therefore, the wise and the learned understand that there is no self.

original: gzhan yang ci'i rgyu dang ci'i rkyen gyis sems can gyis bdag tu 'dzin snyam du rtog ste /
analyzed: gzhan yang ci'i rgyu dang ci'i rkyen gyis sems can gyis bdag tu 'dzin snyam du rtog ste /
translated: ‚Äú ‚ÄòFurthermore, what are the causes and conditions for sentient beings to grasp at a self?

original: bdag de yod pa zhig yin na bdag de gcig tu zad dam /üîΩmang du yod snyam rtog go //
analyzed: bdag de yod pa zhig yin na bdag de gcig tu zad dam / mang du yod snyam rtog go //
translated: If such a self exists, is it singular or multiple?

original: gal te bdag @412b de gcig tu zad na ci'i phyir rgyal rigs dang / bram ze dang / rje'u rigs dang / gdol rigs dang / lha dang / mi dang / sems can dmyal ba dang / yi dvags dang / byol song gi skye gnas dang /
analyzed: gal te bdag @412b de gcig tu zad na ci'i phyir rgyal rigs dang / bram ze dang / rje'u rigs dang / gdol rigs dang / lha dang / mi dang / sems can dmyal ba dang / yi dvags dang / byol song gi skye gnas dang /
translated: ‚Äô ‚Äú ‚ÄòIf the self is singular, why are there brahmins, warriors, merchants, and outcastes, gods, humans, hell beings, starving spirits, and animals,

original: chen po dang / chung ngu dang / lang tsho ba dang / rgas pa yod par gyur /
analyzed: chen po dang / chung ngu dang / lang tsho ba dang / rgas pa yod par gyur /
translated: and why are there large and small, young and old?

original: de bas na bdag ces bya ba ni gcig ma yin par rig go /
analyzed: de bas na bdag ces bya ba ni gcig ma yin par rig go /
translated: Therefore, know that what is called the self is not singular.

original: bdag ces bya ba de gal te mang na ci'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi bdag ces bya ba de gcig ste /
analyzed: bdag ces bya ba de gal te mang na ci'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi bdag ces bya ba de gcig ste /
translated: If what is called the self is multiple, why do all sentient beings say, ‚ÄúThis is my self,‚Äù

original: thams cad du khyab la mtha' med do zhes smra /
analyzed: thams cad du khyab la mtha' med do zhes smra /
translated: and why do they say that it is singular, all-pervading, and without end?

original: de bas na gcig dang mang po gnyis ka la bdag med do //
analyzed: de bas na gcig dang mang po gnyis ka la bdag med do //
translated: Therefore, neither the one nor the many have a self.

original: mkhas pa shes rab can gyis de ltar bdag med par rtogs nas rim gyis kha zas yongs su spong bar byed pa'i 'du shes la rtog ste /
analyzed: mkhas pa shes rab can gyis de ltar bdag med par rtogs nas rim gyis kha zas yongs su spong bar byed pa'i 'du shes la rtog ste /
translated: The wise and the learned, having understood in this way that there is no self, gradually conceive the idea of giving up food.

original: 'di snyam du gal te chos thams cad mi rtag pa'ang yin la sdug bsngal ba dang bdag med pa yin na /
analyzed: 'di snyam du gal te chos thams cad mi rtag pa'ang yin la sdug bsngal ba dang bdag med pa yin na /
translated: They think, ‚ÄúIf all phenomena are impermanent, suffering, and without self,

original: ci'i phyir kha zas kyi phyir lus dang ngag dang yid kyi las mi dge ba bskyed par gyur /
analyzed: ci'i phyir kha zas kyi phyir lus dang ngag dang yid kyi las mi dge ba bskyed par gyur /
translated: why do I generate unwholesome actions of body, speech, and mind for the sake of food?

original: sems can gyis kha zas la chags pa'i phyir lus dang ngag dang yid kyi las mi dge ba byas te /
analyzed: sems can gyis kha zas la chags pa'i phyir lus dang ngag dang yid kyi las mi dge ba byas te /
translated: Sentient beings commit unwholesome actions of body, speech, and mind because of attachment to food.

original: zang zing thob pa rnams gzhan dang thun mong du gyur kyang sdug bsngal gyi rnam par smin pa myong ba na thun mong du len pa med do //
analyzed: zang zing thob pa rnams gzhan dang thun mong du gyur kyang sdug bsngal gyi rnam par smin pa myong ba na thun mong du len pa med do //
translated: Even though the gains and honors they obtain are shared with others, when they experience the ripening of suffering, there is no one to share it with them.

original: rigs kyi bu /
analyzed: rigs kyi bu /
translated: Son of noble family!

original: mkhas pa shes rab can ni gzhan yang 'di ltar rtog ste /
analyzed: mkhas pa shes rab can ni gzhan yang 'di ltar rtog ste /
translated: The wise and the learned also think in this way:

original: sems can thams cad ni kha zas kyi phyir lus dang sems sdug bsngal bar gyur to //
analyzed: sems can thams cad ni kha zas kyi phyir lus dang sems sdug bsngal bar gyur to //
translated: All sentient beings suffer physically and mentally for the sake of food.

original: de ltar sdug bsngal mang po'i @413a *//
analyzed: de ltar sdug bsngal mang po'i @413a *//
translated: In this way, the conditions for many sufferingsüîΩare fulfilled by obtaining food. So why should I generate a mind of attachment to that food?

original: rkyen gyis kha zas thob par gyur na bdag gis ci'i phyir kha zas de la chags pa'i sems bskyed snyam du bsams nas kha zas la chags pa'i sems skye bar mi byed do //
analyzed: rkyen gyis kha zas thob par gyur na bdag gis ci'i phyir kha zas de la chags pa'i sems bskyed snyam du bsams nas kha zas la chags pa'i sems skye bar mi byed do //
translated: Thinking in this way, do not generate a mind of attachment to food.

original: gzhan yang mkhas pa shes rab can gyis lus kyi rgyu gang yin pa brtags na /
analyzed: gzhan yang mkhas pa shes rab can gyis lus kyi rgyu gang yin pa brtags na /
translated: Moreover, when the wise and the learned investigate the cause of the body,

original: de ni kha zas kyi rkyen gyis lus skye zhing 'phel bar rtogs so //
analyzed: de ni kha zas kyi rkyen gyis lus skye zhing 'phel bar rtogs so //
translated: they understand that the body arises and grows due to the condition of food.

original: da bdag gis khyim nas khyim ma yin par rab tu byung ste /
analyzed: da bdag gis khyim nas khyim ma yin par rab tu byung ste /
translated: Now, I have gone forth from home to homelessness

original: tshul khrims mnos pa'ang lus 'di yongs su gtong bar byed de /
analyzed: tshul khrims mnos pa'ang lus 'di yongs su gtong bar byed de /
translated: and have taken up the precepts of ethical discipline in order to give up this body.

original: da kha zas la chags na lus 'di ji ltar gtang bar bya snyam rtog ste /
analyzed: da kha zas la chags na lus 'di ji ltar gtang bar bya snyam rtog ste /
translated: If I now become attached to food, how can I give up this body?

original: de ltar brtags nas kha zas len mod kyi 'brog dgon pa'i yi dvags kyis bu'i sha la za ba tsam gyi 'du shes bskyed de /
analyzed: de ltar brtags nas kha zas len mod kyi 'brog dgon pa'i yi dvags kyis bu'i sha la za ba tsam gyi 'du shes bskyed de /
translated: Having examined it in this way, he accepts food, but he generates the perception that it is like a ghost in a desolate land eating the flesh of its child.

original: yongs su skyo ba'i sems bskyed nas de la chags par mi byed do //
analyzed: yongs su skyo ba'i sems bskyed nas de la chags par mi byed do //
translated: He generates the thought of complete disgust and does not become attached to it.

original: de ltar kha zas la skyon mang po yod par rtogs nas mthar gyis reg pa'i kha zas la 'di ltar rtog go /
analyzed: de ltar kha zas la skyon mang po yod par rtogs nas mthar gyis reg pa'i kha zas la 'di ltar rtog go /
translated: ‚Äú ‚ÄòIn this way, having realized that food has many faults, he gradually examines the food of contact.

original: dper na / ba'i ko ba bshus na srin bu tshad med pa snyed kyis yongs su za ba ltar rtog go /
analyzed: dper na / ba'i ko ba bshus na srin bu tshad med pa snyed kyis yongs su za ba ltar rtog go /
translated: He thinks, ‚ÄúIt is like a hideless cow being devoured by countless insects.

original: gzhan yang mthar gyis bsam pa'i zas la 'di ltar rtog ste /
analyzed: gzhan yang mthar gyis bsam pa'i zas la 'di ltar rtog ste /
translated: ‚Äù He also gradually examines the food of thought.

translated: The monk Gautama is arrogant about his caste and has a good complexion.

original: sngon sbyin pa byin pa'i rkyen gyis rnyed pa mang du rnyed de /
analyzed: sngon sbyin pa byin pa'i rkyen gyis rnyed pa mang du rnyed de /
translated: Because of the conditions of giving alms in the past, he has obtained much wealth.

original: dngos po de dag la snyems pas nga rgyal chen po skyes la /
analyzed: dngos po de dag la snyems pas nga rgyal chen po skyes la /
translated: Because of being conceited about those things, he has given rise to great pride.

original: gzhan yang rig sngags la mkhas pa'i rkyen gyis nga rgyal byed do //
analyzed: gzhan yang rig sngags la mkhas pa'i rkyen gyis nga rgyal byed do //
translated: Moreover, because of being skilled in spells, he acts with pride.

original: de'i rgyu de'i rkyen gyis dka' ba spyod mi nus kyi gos dang mal cha la sogs pa shin tu 'jam pa la sogs te /
analyzed: de'i rgyu de'i rkyen gyis dka' ba spyod mi nus kyi gos dang mal cha la sogs pa shin tu 'jam pa la sogs te /
translated: Because of those causes and conditions, he is unable to practice austerities, but he uses very soft clothes, bedding, and so forth.

original: de bas na 'jig rten na gang zag ma rungs pa thams cad ni rnyed pa dang grags pa 'dod pa'i phyir de'i 'khor du 'du zhing de'i drung du 'dus nas dka' ba ni spyod mi nus so //
analyzed: de bas na 'jig rten na gang zag ma rungs pa thams cad ni rnyed pa dang grags pa 'dod pa'i phyir de'i 'khor du 'du zhing de'i drung du 'dus nas dka' ba ni spyod mi nus so //
translated: Therefore, in the world, all wicked people gather in the retinue of those who desire gain and fame. Having gathered in their presence, they are unable to practice austerities.
